EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (19 CCR 2745.3)

ES - 1.0  FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY

The owners, management, and employees of the Butte County Rice Growers Association, Supply Division (Supply Division) Facility (Facility) located at 1121 Richvale Highway, Richvale, California in Butte County, are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Consolidated Emergency Response/Contingency Plan (CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.



ES - 2.0  FACILITY INFORMATION

?*  The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in Northern California.



?*  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and converted to aqua ammonia. The aqua ammonia is stored, dispensed, and distributed for application as crop production nutrient. 



?*  Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck (and intermittently, by railcar) and stored in four storage tanks (bullets). The bullets have the following liquid (water) capacities



Vessel           Vessel Capacity     Maximum Volume      Amount of NH3 

Bullet 1         15,000 gals             12,750 gals                65,535 lbs

Bullet 2         18,000 gals             15,300 gals                78,642 lbs

Bullet 3         14,000 gals             10,200 gals                52,428 lbs

Bullet 4         12,000 gals             11,900 gals                61,166 lbs

Totals           59,000 gals             50,150 gals               257,771 lbs



The maximum amount of anhydrous ammonia on site is 257,771 lbs.



??  Aqua ammonia is produced in on-site converters and stored in eight (8) tanks

which have a total capacity of 477,000 gallons. 



Vessel            Vessel Capacity         Maximum Volume       Amount of NH4OH 

Tank 1             65,000 gals             55,250 gals                419,900 lbs

Tank 2             65,000 gals             55,250 gals                419,900 lbs

Tank 3             65,000 gals             55,250 gals                419,900 lbs

Tank 4             65,000 gals             55,250 gals                419,900 lbs

Tank 5             65,000 gals             55,250 gals                419,900 lbs

Tank 6             56,000 gals             47,600 gals                361,760 lbs

Tank 7             56,000 gals             47,600 gals                361,760 lbs

Tank 8             40,000 gals             34,000 gals                258,400 lbs

Totals            477,000 gals            405,450 gals              3,081,420 lbs



The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that could be present on site is 3,081,420 pounds. The amount of anhydrous ammonia contained within the aqua ammonia solution, if all the tanks were filled to maximum capacity, is 750,083  pounds. 



    Aqua ammonia, 20% nitrogen by weight, has a liquid density of 7.6 lbs per gallon.

    Aqua ammonia, 20% nitrogen by weight, has 1.85 pounds of ammonia per gallon. 





ES - 3.0    THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes. The results of the evaluation are provided in the Risk Management Plan (RMP).



Anhydrous Ammonia Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 78,642 pounds of anhydrous ammonia; this represents the volume of the largest storage tank administratively limited at 85% of capacity. The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident) is a release from a broken 2 inch di

ameter pipe with an increased wind speed and "D" stability modeling parameters.



Aqua Ammonia Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. The worst-case scenario is failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 419,900 pounds of aqua ammonia that forms a liquid pool (equivalent to a release of 102,212.5 pounds of NH3). The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident) is a release from a pipe break modeled with an increased wind speed and "D" Stability modeling parameters.



ES - 4.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.



Safety Information:  Supply Division ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees. The most recent review of safety information pertaining to the covered processes took place on March 25, 2016. 



Hazard Review:  A hazard review of the regulated processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. The most recent update of the hazard review was conducted on September 29, 2016. Results indicate that no high risk hazards were identified through the hazard review update.



Operating Procedures:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed. The operating procedures were last reviewed on March 25, 2016.



Training:  The Supply Division Facility staff, and Butte County Rice Growers Association corporate staff, understand that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. The training program was last reviewed on March 25, 2016. The current training

findings. The most recent compliance audit was conducted on March 2015. Cal/OSHA conducted an audit of the facility on March 12, 2016.



Incident Investigation:  An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed. In addition to the prevention program elements described above, the following chemical-specific prevention steps have been implemented.



Employee Participation:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Facility has implemented procedures regarding employee participation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.



Hot Work Permit:  With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, the Supply Division has developed a written Hot Work Permit to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements.



Contractor Safety:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Supply Division. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia.



In addition to the prevention program elements described above, the following chemical-specific prevention steps have been implemented.

Anhydrous Ammonia and Aqua Ammonia:  The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines and regulations for these regulated substances



?*  California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Division 1, Chapter 4, Subchapter 1, Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders; 



*  Compressed Gas Association (CGA) Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, CGA 2.1-2014 edition [previously American National Standards Instit

ute, Inc. (ANSI) K61.1, 1999 ed.]; and



*  United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.



ES - 5.0    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed. 



ES - 6.0    THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The Consolidated Emergency Response/Contingency Plan (CCP) was most recently updated in December 2008 and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.



ES - 7.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.
